title: Chloe Rogozinski
text: I’m a Master’s student in Ecosystem Science and Sustainability at Colorado State University, specializing in Water Resources, and the Co-founder and CEO of Reef Healers, where I lead conservation, education, and community engagement that connects inland water stewardship to ocean and coral reef health.

title: About
text:
I am a Master’s student in Ecosystem Science and Sustainability at Colorado State University, specializing in Water Resources. As the Co-founder and CEO of Reef Healers, I lead conservation, education, and community engagement initiatives that connect inland water action to ocean health.

My work focuses on the deep connection between water quality, river systems, and coral reef resilience. I am certified in coral restoration and am scuba certified, bringing hands-on restoration experience into my broader mission of protecting ecosystems from mountains to reefs.

I founded Reef Healers to empower inland communities to understand their influence on marine environments and to take meaningful action. Through science-based communication, outreach, and innovation, I aim to build a movement that strengthens water stewardship, supports community resilience, and protects ecosystems across entire watersheds.

title: Projects
text:
Personal Website & Portfolio
This Quarto-based website serves as my personal portfolio, blog, and learning space for web development and data science. Built with Quarto, it is deployed on GitHub Pages and customized using YAML and SCSS.


Other Projects
Through the class ESS 523A - Environmental Data Science Applications for Ecosystem Science at CSU, I have completed several projects, including a few GitHub repositories which can be viewed on my GitHub site linked below.
View GitHub Projects: https://github.com/crogozinski14

Land Use Regulations on Sensitive Habitats (e.g., barrens) in ColoradoLand Use Regulations on Sensitive Habitats (e.g., barrens) in Colorado
Jan 2025 - May 2025
The Colorado Natural Heritage Program (CNHP) monitors the state’s rare and imperiled species and habitats to promote the conservation of Colorado’s valuable biological resources. Our research group had been tasked with developing a classification workflow for barrens to aid in the protection of these vulnerable ecosystems. With pressure from oil and gas industry expansion, it is pertinent that the 2025 State Wildlife Action Plan (SWAP) includes a clear definition and identification method to ensure uniform understanding across the board in terms of ineligible land for drilling and fracking. With help from CNHP’s existing data and other researched layers, a replicable model for identifying barrens has been initialized to strengthen protection efforts and guide conservation priorities.

Model trial for Alamosa County, CO


Non-point Source Pollution Education
Through my business, Reef Healers, we have launched a project to educate communities on the impacts that inland communities have on ocean health through our connected water, with a primary focus on non-point source pollution. We do this through online education, infographics, and hosting local clean-up events.
